description: A 60-second lesson on Isotype: The First Universal Picture Language.

hook.text: In 1920s Vienna, a philosopher created a picture language so anyone could understand data â€” literate or not.

buildup.text: Otto Neurath invented Isotype â€” rows of identical icons where each icon represents a fixed quantity.

discovery.text: Instead of bar heights, Isotype used repeating symbols. Ten people icons meant ten thousand citizens.

twist.text: Neurath fled the Nazis. His system survived and directly inspired modern infographic icon design.

climax.text: Every restroom sign, airport icon, and infographic pictogram traces its DNA back to Isotype.

punchline.text: He made data readable without words.

quiz.question: What was the purpose of Otto Neurath's Isotype system?
options: To create a universal picture-based data language
